questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) In line manual stabilization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The in-line manual stabilization technique is crucial for patients with potential cervical spine injuries to prevent further spinal damage during airway management and other procedures. It is used to stabilize the head and neck in a neutral position without applying any movement to the cervical spine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cefazolin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line antibiotic for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery is cefazolin due to its effective coverage against skin flora, including Staphylococcus aureus, which are the primary organisms responsible for surgical site infections.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is found lying face down on the ground by a bystander who notes that she is unresponsive. The bystander is trained in basic life support and checks for responsiveness and breathing. The patient is not responding to verbal commands or physical stimuli, but she is breathing shallowly. The bystander notes a weak carotid pulse. Emergency medical services have been activated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Turn the patient onto her back and begin chest compressions.

options.label: B
options.text: Maintain the patient in the prone position and wait for emergency medical services.

options.label: C
options.text: Move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway.

options.label: D
options.text: Provide rescue breathing while keeping the patient in the current position.

questions.correct_answer: C. Move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For unresponsive patients with a pulse and spontaneous breathing, place them in the recovery position to maintain airway patency and reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the composition of a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics (EMLA)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lidocaine and prilocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EMLA cream, a eutectic mixture of lidocaine and prilocaine, is commonly used to achieve topical anesthesia for minor dermatological procedures and needle-related procedures, providing effective local pain relief.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia team needs to ensure the proper connection of the oxygen supply. Which of the following PIN (Pin-Index) configurations corresponds to the oxygen supply in medical gas cylinders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pin Index Safety System (PISS) is crucial for preventing accidental connection of the wrong gas to medical equipment. Oxygen is specifically assigned the pin configuration of 2 and 5 to enhance safety in medical settings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of severe anxiety is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure. The anaesthesia team decides to use a dissociative anesthetic for induction. Which of the following drugs is a commonly used dissociative anaesthetic and is suitable for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is a commonly used dissociative anesthetic, providing both anesthesia and analgesia, which can be advantageous for minor surgical procedures and anxious patients. It maintains cardiovascular stability and airway reflexes, making it unique among anesthetic agents.

questions.text: Identify the laryngeal mask airway from the picture below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Proseal LMA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Proseal LMA is a reusable laryngeal mask airway with a dual-channel design, allowing for ventilation and gastric drainage, making it suitable for patients at risk of aspiration. This feature differentiates it from other LMAs that may lack a gastric access port or have different structural designs.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was posted for appendectomy. On further examination child was not even allowing touching by anaesthesiologist. It was decided to take child for inhalational induction of anaesthesia. Which of the following will be the inhalational agent of choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is preferred for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-irritating nature and rapid onset of action, making it a more comfortable and efficient choice for children who may not tolerate IV induction well.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoing elective orthopedic surgery requires neuromuscular blockade. Given his history of malignant hyperthermia, the anesthesiologist opts to use a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Which additional agent should be avoided in this patient due to potential exacerbation of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Isoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of malignant hyperthermia, volatile anesthetics (such as isoflurane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants should be avoided due to their potential to trigger an MH crisis. Safe alternatives include intravenous agents like propofol and non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers.

questions.text: During a complex abdominal surgery, the anesthesiologist decides to use a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent for muscle relaxation. Which of the following patient factors would necessitate an adjustment in the dosing regimen of this medication?
questions.correct_answer: A. Concurrent use of aminoglycoside antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Concurrent use of aminoglycoside antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Certain medications, such as aminoglycosides, can potentiate the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, requiring dose adjustments to prevent prolonged neuromuscular blockade. It is essential to assess drug interactions in perioperative management to ensure patient safety.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female is scheduled for a total hip replacement. To monitor neuromuscular blockade, the anesthesiologist decides to use a nerve stimulator. Considering the patient's history of peripheral neuropathy, which nerve should be avoided for monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Peroneal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with peripheral neuropathy affecting the lower limbs, it is advisable to avoid using the peroneal nerve for neuromuscular blockade monitoring. Upper extremity nerves such as the ulnar or median nerve are preferred to minimize the risk of exacerbating neuropathy or obtaining unreliable measurements.

questions.text: A patient with a known genetic susceptibility to pseudocholinesterase deficiency requires an emergency C-section under general anesthesia. Which of the following muscle relaxants should be avoided to prevent prolonged neuromuscular blockade?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Succinylcholine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, avoid the use of succinylcholine due to the risk of prolonged neuromuscular blockade. Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as cisatracurium, pancuronium, and vecuronium, are preferred as they do not rely on pseudocholinesterase for metabolism.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Class II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mallampati classification helps predict the ease of intubation by evaluating visible structures in the oropharynx. Recognizing these classifications, particularly in pre-anesthetic assessments, can aid in planning airway management strategies.
  • ➤ Mallampati classification

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. Anesthesia is induced without any complications, and the patient is intubated using a cuffed endotracheal tube. During the surgical procedure, you notice a change in the capnography waveform. Instead of a normal square waveform, there is a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase and a decreased end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) value. Based on the capnography findings, what is the most likely explanation for the observed changes?

options.label: C
options.text: Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system

questions.correct_answer: C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A gradual upslope in the expiratory phase of the capnography waveform with decreased ETCO₂ can indicate increased airway resistance or partial airway obstruction. Recognizing capnography patterns is crucial for early identification of respiratory complications during anesthesia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who is a known hypertensive is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy under general anesthesia. Post the surgery his serum creatinine goes up to 4.5 and he has kidney failure. What could be the causative inhalational agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Methoxyflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methoxyflurane is known for its potential to cause renal damage due to high fluoride ion production upon metabolism. For patients with or at risk of renal impairment, inhalational agents with minimal metabolism, such as desflurane or isoflurane, are preferred to reduce the risk of nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A patient with a history of severe asthma is scheduled for an appendectomy. Which of the following induction agents will cause the least respiratory depression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is the preferred induction agent in asthmatic patients due to its bronchodilatory effect and minimal respiratory depression. This makes it an excellent choice for patients with reactive airway diseases undergoing surgery.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is scheduled for an emergency exploratory laparotomy due to a suspected intestinal obstruction. Considering his cardiac history, the anesthesiologist must choose an induction agent that will cause the least myocardial depression while maintaining hemodynamic stability. Which intravenous anesthetic should be selected for the induction of anesthesia in this patient to minimize the risk of myocardial depression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Etomidate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etomidate is the induction agent of choice in patients with cardiac compromise, as it provides hemodynamic stability with minimal myocardial depression, reducing the risk of hypotension and cardiovascular instability during induction.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath. On physical examination, he appears to be in respiratory distress. The resident decides to assess his oxygenation status immediately using a non-invasive device. Which of the following is most accurately measured by the device applied to the patient's finger as shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulse oximetry is an essential, non-invasive tool used for real-time monitoring of oxygen saturation (SpO₂) in patients. However, it does not provide details about ventilation, oxygen content, or acid-base status and may have limitations in certain clinical scenarios.

questions.text: During an anesthetic procedure, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension accidentally receives an intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone. Immediately after the injection, he reports severe pain at the injection site and the affected limb becomes pale. Which of the following is the most likely complication this patient is experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ischemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to ischemic complications due to vasospasm. Recognizing the signs and symptoms of this complication is essential for prompt intervention to prevent lasting ischemic damage to the affected limb.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Thiopentone?

options.label: A
options.text: Induction dose is 3-5 mg/kg of 2.5% thiopentone.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces ICP and is Cerebroprotective

options.label: C
options.text: It is ultra-short acting due to rapid metabolism & excretion.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is ultra-short acting due to rapid metabolism & excretion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is ultra-short acting due to rapid metabolism & excretion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiopentone’s ultra-short action is due to redistribution to peripheral tissues, not rapid metabolism and excretion. Its applications include neuroprotection due to its ability to lower ICP.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a minor ambulatory surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist plans to use an induction agent that allows for rapid emergence post-procedure. Which of the following agent is the preferred induction agent used in day care surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Propofol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propofol is the induction agent of choice for day care surgeries due to its rapid onset and recovery, allowing patients to awaken and recover swiftly after short procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the preferred non-invasive method for evaluating perioperative cardiac risk in patients unable to undergo exercise testing, as it provides reliable prognostic information on myocardial function and ischemia.

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inspiration with cardiac oscillations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac oscillations on a capnograph appear as a series of small, regular oscillations on the expiratory plateau. These are caused by cardiac movements affecting lung or airway pressures and are often observed in patients under controlled ventilation with no spontaneous breaths.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of supraventricular tachycardia with hemodynamic instability, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice to restore normal rhythm and improve perfusion. Medications such as adenosine or diltiazem are reserved for stable patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of respiratory failure has been on mechanical ventilation for one week in the ICU. Suddenly, the patient becomes agitated and self-extubates. What is the recommended next step in managing this situation?

options.label: D
options.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if needed

questions.correct_answer: D. Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if needed
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if needed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unplanned extubation, it is important to assess for spontaneous breathing and ensure that the patient maintains adequate oxygenation. Re-intubation should be considered only if respiratory status is compromised, not as an automatic response.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his etCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The take-home point is to recognize venous air embolism as a potential complication during neck surgeries, especially when large veins are involved. A sudden drop in end-tidal CO₂, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmia should raise suspicion for venous air embolism in this surgical context.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Automated External Defibrillator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The take-home point is to recognize the appearance and purpose of an Automated External Defibrillator (AED). AEDs are crucial, life-saving devices used in emergencies to treat sudden cardiac arrest by delivering an electric shock to restore normal heart rhythm.

questions.text: A patient of blunt chest trauma has been intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not correct about the initial setting?

options.label: D
options.text: Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual body weight

questions.correct_answer: D. Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual body weight
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual body weight

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The take-home point is to recognize appropriate initial ventilator settings for patients with chest trauma or lung injury. For such patients, it is essential to set a tidal volume of 6-8 ml/kg of ideal body weight to minimize the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ End-tidal CO₂ monitoring is considered the gold standard for verifying endotracheal tube placement. It provides immediate, continuous, and reliable confirmation, essential for safe airway management.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a lumbar puncture, the arachnoid mater is the final meningeal layer pierced before accessing the subarachnoid space for CSF sampling. Recognizing the anatomical layers traversed during this procedure is essential for safe and effective lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CPR with 20% intralipid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The take-home point is that in cases of suspected local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) with agents like bupivacaine, 20% intralipid therapy should be initiated alongside CPR to help mitigate toxicity and improve the chances of successful resuscitation.

questions.text: What is the maximum Fio2 given by the device below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 80%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The take-home point is that a non-rebreather mask can deliver high concentrations of oxygen, approximately 80-90%, making it suitable for patients requiring significant supplemental oxygen but not immediate intubation. Proper flow rate adjustment is necessary to maximize the FiO₂ delivered.

questions.text: Which complications are incorrectly paired with volatile anesthetic agents?
questions.correct_answer: B. Bone marrow depression and Halothane
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Given below are the specific toxicities of volatile anesthetics:
  • ➤ • Desflurane/Isoflurane → CO production
  • ➤ • Sevoflurane → Compound A (renal risk)
  • ➤ • Nitrous oxide → Vitamin B12 inactivation (macrocytic anemia)
  • ➤ • Halothane → Liver toxicity, not bone marrow suppression

questions.text: Which one is not the original criteria for post anaesthesia Aldrete Morgan Recovery Score?

options.label: A
options.text: Able to breathe deeply and cough freely

questions.correct_answer: D. Post-operative pain, nausea and vomiting
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Post-operative pain, nausea and vomiting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Aldrete Score focuses on respiratory function, circulation, consciousness, and motor activity to assess recovery from anesthesia, excluding factors like post-operative pain, nausea, and vomiting in its original criteria.

questions.text: A 20-kg, 6-year-old girl develops pulseless ventricular tachycardia. As per 2005 American Heart Association Guidelines for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation what should be the energy level for the initial shock?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 Joules (J)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended initial defibrillation energy for children with pulseless ventricular tachycardia is 2 Joules per kilogram, followed by 4 Joules per kilogram if additional shocks are needed.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 10 L/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maximum oxygen flow rate for a conventional Hudson (simple face) mask is 10 L/min, which provides a moderate concentration of oxygen suitable for patients requiring supplemental oxygen without high-flow demands.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology PFT- Pulmonary function test FEV1 – Forced expiratory volume in 1 second FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with an FEV1 < 0.8 and an FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.7 on post-bronchodilator testing are more likely to have clinically significant obstructive lung disease, which may impact anesthetic risk and management. Identifying these thresholds allows for timely intervention and optimization in preoperative planning.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for CPR in Basic life support?

options.label: A
options.text: Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

options.label: B
options.text: Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate

options.label: C
options.text: Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, Maintain airway

options.label: D
options.text: Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.correct_answer: A. Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The BLS sequence prioritizes assessing responsiveness, activating the Emergency Response System, and confirming pulselessness before initiating CPR. This order ensures timely intervention and readiness for advanced support if needed.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the casualty unconscious and with unrecordable BP. CPR is started. The ECG shows asystole. What is the shock energy to be delivered via the defibrillator?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asystole is a non-shockable rhythm, and defibrillation is not indicated. The management of asystole includes high-quality CPR and administration of medications like epinephrine to try to achieve a return of spontaneous circulation.

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding Pediatric ACLS guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Cuffed endotracheal tube is not preferred due to chance of tracheal stenosis

options.label: B
options.text: Depth of chest compressions is equal to A-P diameter

options.label: C
options.text: First shock energy to be delivered is 3 J/kg

options.label: D
options.text: In infants after intubation respiratory rate should be 20-30 breaths /min

questions.correct_answer: D. In infants after intubation respiratory rate should be 20-30 breaths /min
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) In infants after intubation respiratory rate should be 20-30 breaths /min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct respiratory rate for infants after intubation is 20-30 breaths per minute. Pediatric resuscitation guidelines have evolved, recommending cuffed tubes in most cases, compressions to one-third of the chest diameter, and an initial shock energy of 2 J/kg for defibrillation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old young truck driver has developed a fissure in ano. What would be the ideal anesthesia for this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Saddle anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Saddle anesthesia is the preferred choice for procedures involving the perineum, like fissure in ano, as it provides targeted anesthetic coverage to the relevant area without affecting the entire lower body.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child is undergoing surgical repair of umbilical hernia under general anesthesia. Identify the procedure performed in the picture below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Caudal anaesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caudal anesthesia, performed through the sacral hiatus, is commonly used in pediatric patients for lower abdominal and perineal surgeries. It provides effective regional anesthesia with minimal systemic impact and is suitable for infants and young children.

questions.text: Mendelson’s syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aspiration during general anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mendelson's syndrome describes aspiration pneumonitis that occurs from the inhalation of acidic gastric contents during general anesthesia. This condition underscores the importance of proper preoperative fasting and precautions in at-risk patients to minimize aspiration risks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida is taken for emergency LSCS due to fetal distress. She had a cup of tea 8 hours ago. Which of these need not be followed for induction of general anesthesia in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Keep adequate blood and blood products ready

questions.correct_answer: D. Keep adequate blood and blood products ready
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In emergency obstetric anesthesia, the focus is on securing the airway and minimizing the risk of aspiration. Having a difficult airway cart and performing rapid sequence induction are standard practices, while blood products are only prepared if there is an anticipated risk of significant bleeding.

questions.text: Assertion : General Anaesthesia is the preferred technique of anaesthesia in emergency obstetric surgeries. Reason : General anesthesia is more comfortable for parturients who have fear of needles or surgery

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement.

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ General anesthesia is often selected in emergency obstetric surgeries due to its ability to provide rapid and controlled anesthesia, which is critical in time-sensitive situations. Patient comfort is a consideration but not the primary reason for this choice in emergencies.

questions.text: A child with upper respiratory tract infection needs to be taken for emergency foreign body removal from esophagus. What would be the inhalational agent of choice in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sevoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for pediatric patients with upper respiratory infections requiring anesthesia, as it provides rapid induction with minimal airway irritation, reducing the risk of complications such as laryngospasm.

questions.text: You are asked to take intravenous access for a 3-year-old child who is going to undergo tonsillectomy under general anesthesia. Identify the gauge of IV cannula commonly used in pediatrics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 26G

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pediatric intravenous access, particularly in young children, a smaller gauge cannula, like 26G, is preferred to minimize vein trauma, ensure comfort, and facilitate reliable access for anesthesia administration.

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding difference between adult and pediatric airway?

options.label: A
options.text: Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics.

options.label: C
options.text: Epiglottis is at a higher level in children than adults.

options.label: D
options.text: Larynx is funnel shaped in children

questions.correct_answer: A. Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding anatomical differences between pediatric and adult airways is essential for airway management. Children have a larger tongue-to-mouth ratio, a higher and more anterior larynx, a floppy epiglottis, and a funnel-shaped larynx, all of which impact techniques and considerations in pediatric airway management.

questions.text: Calculate the maintenance fluid for the first hour of surgery in a child weighing 10 kg?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 40 ml/hr

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pediatric patients, the "4-2-1 rule" provides a quick method to calculate hourly maintenance fluid needs. A 10 kg child requires 40 ml/hr, helping ensure proper hydration and electrolyte balance during surgery.

questions.text: Identify the use of the equipment shown below in the picture?

options.label: A
options.text: For intubation in an anticipated difficult airway

options.label: B
options.text: Guide placement of double lumen tube

options.label: C
options.text: Suction of blood from the airways

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fiberoptic bronchoscope is a versatile tool in anesthesia and critical care, facilitating intubation in difficult airways, guiding double lumen tube placement, and allowing for suctioning of the airways. Its multiple applications make it invaluable in airway management.
